title: Is this sentence correct 'School is very near my home'? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s not grammatically incorrect, but it’s not the most natural-sounding way to phrase what you’re trying to say. Also, as a creative writing teacher, I usually advise my students to avoid words like “very” in their writing, because it’s a little vague and doesn’t really tell us anything, especially when you consider that what I mean when I say “very near” may not be the same as what you mean and may lead to miscommunication. Another thing to consider is that you’ll hold the reader’s attention better by using specific, concrete words in your descriptions. A native English speaker wouldn’t begin the sentence with just “School.” We’d want to give the reader more information. Something along the lines of “John’s school,” “my school” or “the local high school” is needed. After that, there are about a million ways to convey the information to your reader. “I live close to my school” or “My school is near to my house” sound natural enough, but still don’t tell us much. If you say something like, “My house is only half a mile from the high school” or “There’s a primary school two blocks from my house,” you’ve given your reader good, specific information that makes it easier for him or her to form a mental picture.

It would only make sense in a certain context. If you’re saying it without some very specific context, you would want to say instead, for example: My school is very near my home. That school is very near my home. Mike’s school is very near my home. Without any context, the listener will wonder “What school?” The word school on its own does not convey much meaning. At the very least, you would want “A school” or “The school.” I suppose you could construct a scenario where “School” on its own might work in this sentence, but it would take a lot of thinking to construct it. On another note, “near my home” strikes this American English speaker as rather British and old-fashioned. In the US, we would be much more likely to say: “That school is very close to my home” [even better, “my house,” “my apartment”] or “That school is very close to where I live.” But I wouldn’t call “near my home” wrong. It’s just not the most natrural-sounding way to say it in my variety of English.

Is this sentence correct 'School is very near my home'? In a colloquial sense, yes, the sentence is correct. But to be literally correct it should be: "My school is very near my home," or "The school I attend is very near my home." In order to refer to your school as just "school," which like "home" is a nebulous, not a physical thing, you must have first internalized it. The person to whom you are saying the sentence does not have a specific image of what you mean by "school," because it exists only in your mind. You must first externalize it so the other person can get the meaning of it.

In a casual sense, truly, the sentence is right. Be that as it may, to be actually right it ought to be: "My school is extremely close to my home," or "The school I go to is exceptionally close to my home." So as to allude to your school as simply "school," which like "home" is an undefined, not a physical thing, you should have first disguised it. The individual to whom you are stating the sentence does not have a particular picture of what you mean by "school," since it exists just in your brain. You should first externalize it so the other individual can get its importance.
